encounter.setting: Outpatient CBT clinic — first treatment session
encounter.referral_context: Referred by PCP after 6 months of panic attacks. Full cardiac and thyroid workup negative.

phases.dialogue: These panic attacks are destroying my life. I had to leave work twice last week. I thought I was having a heart attack — my heart was pounding, I couldn't breathe. Now I'm scared to go anywhere crowded in case it happens again.

chart_reveals.label: Primary concern
chart_reveals.value: Recurrent panic attacks with avoidance of public spaces

phases.dialogue: It starts with this sense of doom, then my heart races, I sweat, my hands tingle. Peaks in maybe 10 minutes. Afterward I'm exhausted. Between attacks I'm constantly worried the next one is coming. I've stopped taking the subway, stopped going to malls. My wife is getting frustrated.

chart_reveals.label: Attack characteristics
chart_reveals.value: Palpitations, diaphoresis, paresthesias, sense of impending doom; peaks ~10 min

chart_reveals.label: Avoidance
chart_reveals.value: Subway, malls, crowded venues — progressive restriction over 6 months

chart_reveals.label: Functional impact
chart_reveals.value: Missed 2 work days last week; marital tension

phases.clinician_prompt: Can you walk me through what happens during a typical attack and how you cope afterward?

phases.dialogue: When my heart races I think 'this is it — I'm going to die or lose control.' I know logically the doctors said it's not my heart. But in the moment I completely believe it. Afterward I feel stupid for believing it, but the next attack comes and I believe it all over again.

chart_reveals.label: Thought content
chart_reveals.value: Catastrophic appraisals during panic: 'I am dying / losing control / going crazy'

chart_reveals.label: Insight
chart_reveals.value: Good inter-episode insight; absent during acute panic state — dual-level belief

chart_reveals.label: Mood/Affect
chart_reveals.value: Anxious mood; congruent affect; no depressive features

phases.clinician_prompt: What thoughts go through your mind during the worst moment of an attack?

questions.prompt: This patient has Panic Disorder with agoraphobic avoidance. Which CBT component is MOST critical for long-term recovery and must not be omitted?

options.A: Relaxation training and diaphragmatic breathing to manage somatic symptoms
options.B: Interoceptive exposure and in vivo situational exposure to avoided contexts
options.C: Cognitive restructuring of catastrophic beliefs without behavioral exposure
options.D: Psychoeducation about the fight-or-flight response only

questions.explanation: The gold standard for Panic Disorder is CBT with exposure — specifically interoceptive exposure (deliberately inducing feared sensations) and in vivo situational exposure (confronting avoided contexts). Without behavioral exposure, avoidance is maintained, perpetuating the disorder. Cognitive restructuring and psychoeducation are valuable adjuncts but insufficient alone. Relaxation strategies can become safety behaviors that suppress extinction learning if used as escape.

distractor_rationale.A: Breathing techniques can inadvertently function as safety behaviors that prevent extinction learning and maintain avoidance if used as coping escapes during exposure.
distractor_rationale.C: Cognitive restructuring alone has weaker evidence than combined CBT. Avoidance behavior maintains the anxiety cycle regardless of cognitive change.
distractor_rationale.D: Psychoeducation is a necessary starting point but produces minimal symptom reduction when used in isolation without active exposure components.

questions.prompt: The patient has good inter-episode insight but loses it entirely during panic. What is the best CBT strategy to update his 'hot' (in-the-moment) belief that panic causes death?

options.A: Grounding techniques to restore reality contact during dissociative states
options.B: Behavioral experiments — induce panic sensations and test specific predictions
options.C: Purely verbal cognitive restructuring during calm, non-aroused states
options.D: Bibliotherapy about the physiology of panic before any exposure work

questions.explanation: The patient shows 'dual representation' — intellectually accepting medical reassurance but emotionally believing catastrophic thoughts during panic. In CBT, this is addressed through behavioral experiments: deliberately inducing panic-like sensations (interoceptive exposure) while testing specific predictions (e.g., 'I will have a heart attack') in a controlled setting. Repeated disconfirmation during an aroused state updates the emotional 'hot' belief, not just the intellectual 'cold' belief.

distractor_rationale.A: Grounding targets depersonalization/derealization — a dissociative experience not described here. The issue is catastrophic appraisal, not reality contact.
distractor_rationale.C: Verbal restructuring in calm states only updates 'cold' beliefs accessible when not anxious. Beliefs during panic are encoded in a different arousal state and require exposure-based updating.
distractor_rationale.D: Bibliotherapy builds conceptual understanding but does not update in-the-moment emotional beliefs. Active behavioral work is required for exposure learning.

encounter.setting: Intensive outpatient program (IOP) — weekly individual DBT session
encounter.referral_context: Enrolled in DBT IOP after discharge from inpatient unit for superficial self-harm. Diagnosis: Borderline Personality Disorder.

phases.dialogue: Last week was a disaster. My roommate said one thing and I went from fine to rage in about 30 seconds. I scratched myself. It wasn't bad. I didn't want to die.

chart_reveals.label: Presenting crisis
chart_reveals.value: Superficial self-harm (scratching) following interpersonal conflict with roommate

chart_reveals.label: Intent
chart_reveals.value: Denies suicidal intent; self-harm functioned as affect regulation

phases.dialogue: I know what I was supposed to do. TIPP — change body temperature. I put ice on my wrist for like 20 seconds and then gave up. In the moment, scratching felt like it would work faster. And it did. Now I feel disgusted with myself.

chart_reveals.label: Crisis skills attempted
chart_reveals.value: Brief TIPP attempt (ice ~20 sec) — abandoned before effect; self-harm followed

chart_reveals.label: Contingency
chart_reveals.value: Self-harm provided rapid affect regulation; followed by shame and disgust

chart_reveals.label: Affect
chart_reveals.value: Labile; rapid shame-to-anger oscillation during session

phases.clinician_prompt: Walk me through what happened — from the moment your roommate said that to when you scratched.

phases.dialogue: She said I was 'too sensitive' and I immediately thought — she hates me, she wants me to leave, everyone thinks I'm too much. And then I wanted to hurt myself to make her feel bad, and also to feel better. I know that's contradictory.

chart_reveals.label: Thought content
chart_reveals.value: Catastrophic interpersonal interpretation — 'she hates me'; mind-reading

chart_reveals.label: Insight
chart_reveals.value: Emerging — patient identifies contradictory functions of self-harm; limited in-moment

chart_reveals.label: Interpersonal pattern
chart_reveals.value: Intense unstable relationships; hypersensitivity to rejection; fear of abandonment

phases.clinician_prompt: What did that thought — 'she wants me to leave' — feel like in your body?

questions.prompt: In the DBT hierarchy of treatment targets, which behavior takes priority in the next session given this week's events?

options.A: Therapy-interfering behaviors — her resistance to fully using skills
options.B: Quality-of-life behaviors — addressing the roommate conflict with DEAR MAN
options.C: Life-threatening behaviors — completing a chain analysis of the self-harm
options.D: Skill building — reteaching the full TIPP skill with correct duration

questions.explanation: DBT organizes treatment targets in a strict hierarchy: (1) Life-threatening behaviors — any suicidal or self-harm behaviors; (2) Therapy-interfering behaviors; (3) Quality-of-life behaviors; (4) Skill acquisition. Despite the patient's low lethality self-harm, it is a Tier 1 target and must be addressed before other targets. The chain analysis — examining antecedents, links, and consequences — is the primary tool for identifying and interrupting the self-harm pathway.

distractor_rationale.A: Therapy-interfering behaviors (Tier 2) are important, but the DBT hierarchy places any life-threatening behavior at Tier 1, which must be addressed first regardless of lethality level.
distractor_rationale.B: Quality-of-life issues (Tier 3) such as interpersonal skills practice are addressed only after Tier 1 and 2 targets. Bypassing the hierarchy undermines the DBT model.
distractor_rationale.D: Skill building is essential but cannot substitute for chain analysis of the self-harm behavior. The chain analysis identifies exactly where skills failed and where to insert new solutions.

questions.prompt: The patient abandoned TIPP after 20 seconds because self-harm 'worked faster.' Which DBT principle explains why brief skill use is insufficient, and why the skill must be sustained?

options.A: Radical acceptance — the patient must accept the urge before acting on it
options.B: Opposite action — she must act contrary to the urge's behavioral impulse
options.C: Urge surfing — emotional urges peak and naturally decrease if not acted upon
options.D: Wise mind — she must integrate emotional and rational thinking before responding

questions.explanation: Urge surfing is the DBT principle that emotional urges and subjective distress follow a natural arc — they intensify, peak, then decrease on their own without action if the person does not feed them. Twenty seconds of TIPP is insufficient because the emotional peak has not passed. The therapist should help the patient understand that distress tolerance skills must be sustained through the urge peak (typically 15–30 minutes). Self-harm 'working faster' means the urge had not yet peaked, not that the skill was ineffective.

distractor_rationale.A: Radical acceptance addresses suffering that comes from resisting painful reality — it does not explain the temporal arc of urge intensity or why skill duration matters.
distractor_rationale.B: Opposite action is an emotion regulation strategy (acting counter to the emotion's action urge) that is relevant here, but it doesn't explain the neurobiological/temporal reason why skills must be sustained.
distractor_rationale.D: Wise mind is a core dialectical concept balancing emotion and reason — foundational to DBT but does not address the dynamics of urge attenuation over time.
